DataElement.preferredName: Cervical Neoplasm Pathologic Margin Involved Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to describe the type of cervical cancer margin involvement.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._A boundary line or the area immediately inside the boundary._To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: (NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.:Margin; the boundary line or the area immediately inside the boundary.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
A boundary line or the area immediately inside the boundary.

Property.preferredDefinition: To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

Concepts.definition: To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.: Relating to the vagina or to any sheath.: Margin; the boundary line or the area immediately inside the boundary.

Concepts.definition: A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.
Of or relating to the vagina.
A boundary line or the area immediately inside the boundary.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.: A distensible musculomembranous organ serving as a receptacle for fluid, as the gallbladder.: Margin; the boundary line or the area immediately inside the boundary.

Concepts.definition: A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.
The distensible sac-like organ that functions as a reservoir of urine, collecting from the kidneys and eliminating via the urethra.
A boundary line or the area immediately inside the boundary.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Microscopic; too small to be seen except under a microscope.: Regions near to the parametrium.

Concepts.definition: Too small to be seen except under a microscope.
Regions near to the parametrium.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Visible to the naked eye.: Regions near to the parametrium.

Concepts.definition: Visible to the naked eye.
Regions near to the parametrium.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

Concepts.definition: A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

Concepts.definition: A benign, malignant, or precancerous neoplasm that affects the cervix.
Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.
A boundary line or the area immediately inside the boundary.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
